Graphical abstract In this paper, Rh catalysts supported over bare γ-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 modified with different promoters (15wt%La2O3 and/or 2.5wt%CeO2) were reported. The catalysts were prepared by successive impregnation: first the rare earth oxide promoter and then Rh. Hydrogen production by ethanol steam reforming (ESR) over these catalysts was investigated. Among the catalysts, Rh/La2O3–CeO2–γ-Al2O3 catalyst shows the highest hydrogen yield as well as the best stability during the reaction. Reaction pathways of the ESR over these Rh catalysts are investigated from the analysis of the adsorbed species and gas phase products formed during temperature programmed desorption of ethanol and ethanol steam reforming reaction. The differences in the reaction pathways and products distribution are as a result of the modification of the stability of some reaction intermediates caused by the presence of a small quantity of CeO2 and La2O3 on the support surfaces: in effect, acetaldehyde was formed as an intermediate over the modified-γ-Al2O3 supported catalysts while in the case of the bare Al2O3 support the main route of the steam reforming reaction is the direct ethanol decomposition. Analysis of the used catalysts by XPS, TGA and RAMAN showed that changes in reaction pathways associated to the presence of promoters in the Al2O3 support also modifies the extension and type of carbon deposited on catalyst surfaces. Keywords Hydrogen production Ethanol Steam reforming Rh catalysts Metal oxide promoters 1 Introduction Decrease in fossil resources and current intensified interest in protecting the environment have led to an imperative search of alternative energy sources. In this regard, hydrogen as energy carrier will play an important role in the energy systems of the future because it could be generated from several renewable sources and transformed into energy with high efficiency. Thus, the production of hydrogen from biomass is receiving increased attention as a potential source of renewable energy. Among the options for hydrogen production from biomass, the steam reforming of ethanol (SRE, Eq. (1)) represents one of the most promising methods because of the high availability of ethanol, its relative low cost and the high H2 production capacity of the process per molecule of ethanol reformed [1–3]. (1) C2H5OH+3H2O→6H2 +2CO2 The ethanol steam reforming reaction is catalyzed by different metals, Ni, Co, Pt, Rh, Ni/Cu, Pt/Ni deposited on different oxide supports (e.g., Al2O3, La2O3, ZnO, CeO2, MgO, etc.) [4–10]. Among transition metals, the high CC bond-breaking activity and the high resistance to coke formation of Rh makes it one of the most studied active phase for ethanol-reforming reactions [6,11–14]. γ-Al2O3 is a common support for steam reforming catalysts because of its thermal and chemical stability under reforming conditions and the possibility that it offers to control the surface area and pore size distribution. However, in the application of γ-Al2O3 in the steam reforming of ethanol it must be taken into account that surface acidity of alumina could produce ethylene, which can be easily dehydrogenated to form coke over metal phases. For that reason the modification of γ-Al2O3 with addition of alkali metals, rare earths oxides and other basic oxides species is frequently reported in the literature. [4,15,16]. Within the rare-earth oxides, the most employed are CeO2 and La2O3. The promoting effect of CeO2 is attributed to: (i), its higher reducibility in the presence of noble metals (ii), the improvement of metal active particles dispersion and, (iii), prevention of sintering of metal particles. Additionally, this type of promoters enables the reversible addition and removal of oxygen which facilitates coke gasification [17–21]. In the case of La2O3, the promoting effect has been attributed to the formation of lanthanum oxycarbonate species (La2O2CO3) which reacts with surface carbon deposited during reaction, and hence preventing deactivation [4,22]. The enhancement of the catalytic performance of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst promoted with rare earth oxides can be attributed to the modification of the reaction pathways during the SRE. According to the literature [23–25], the reaction mechanism on supported noble metal catalysts involves different steps: (i) ethanol dissociative adsorption, (ii) ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde and acetyl species, and (iii) acetaldehyde decomposition to CO and methane, or (iv) oxidation of dehydrogenated species to acetate species by addition of support-bound hydroxyl groups. In addition to these reactions, subsequent reactions such as water gas shift (WGS) and steam reforming of methane (SRM) promote the production of H2 from the CO and methane previously produced. It is generally accepted that reaction mechanism depends on both the metal and support sites. The chemical nature of the promoted support strongly affects the products distribution and catalyst stability during SRE [15,16,26–31]. In this report, γ-Al2O3 has been modified with CeO2, La2O3 and both oxides (CeO2–La2O3), to possibly double the effect since they have shown good results independently. According to previous results [11], the catalyst promoted with 2.5wt%CeO2 on Rh/La2O3–SiO2 showed an increase in the Rh metallic dispersion, but did not improve the stability under reaction conditions. With this background, the objective of this work was to study the effect of low loading of CeO2 on the stability and coke resistance of Rh/γ-Al2O3 and Rh/La2O3–γ-Al2O3 catalysts during the ESR reaction. This work not only provides insights into the active sites and coke resistance on these bi-functional catalysts, but we also propose an explanation about the promoting effect of rare-earth oxides using DRIFTS characterization of the different pathways detected. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Modified supports were prepared by wet-impregnation of a commercial γ-Al2O3 (Girdtler S BET =212m2/g) with the appropriate amount of an aqueous solution of cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9% Merck) and/or lanthanum nitrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9% Merck) as precursor for CeO2 and La2O3, respectively, to obtain 2.5wt%CeO2–Al2O3 and 15wt%La2O3–Al2O3. The resulting slurry was stirred for 4h at RT and the excess solvent was removed by heating at 353K under vacuum in a rotary evaporator. Finally, the obtained solids were dried overnight at 373K, followed by calcination in air at 923K for 6h at a heating rate of 10Kmin−1. When the Al2O3 support was modified with both promoters (2.5wt%CeO2 −15wt%La2O3–Al2O3), cerium was impregnated firs, followed by lanthanum on the calcined CeO2–Al2O3 support, following the same procedure previously described. Rhodium catalysts (∼1wt%) were prepared in a similar way by wet impregnation of the prepared supports using an aqueous rhodium chloride hydrate solution (RhCl3·H2O, 99.9% Aldrich). Calcination was performed for the dried samples under flowing air (30mLmin−1) at 573K for 3h, at a heating rate of 10Kmin−1. The final prepared catalysts were 1%Rh/γ-Al2O3, 1%Rh/2.5%CeO2–γ-Al2O3, 1%Rh/15%La2O3–γ-Al2O3 and 1%Rh/2.5%CeO2–15%La2O3–γ-Al2O3. The samples were designated as Rh/xCe–yLA where CeCeO2, L=La2O3 and A=γ-Al2O3 (x =0 and 2.5wt%, y =0 and 15wt%). 2.2 Catalysts characterization Specific surface areas were obtained from nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77K performed in an automatic Micromeritics apparatus Model ASAP 2010. The isotherms were measured over a range of P/P 0 varied from 0.05 to 0.30. All samples were outgassed at 393K for 0.5h before the adsorption measurements. BET surface areas were calculated from the linear part of the BET plot according to IUPAC recommendations. Particle size was determined by HR-TEM micrographs obtained with a JEOL TEM-2100F. Samples were dispersed on carbon grids after sonicating the samples in H2O:ethanol (50:50) for 0.5h. Up to 300 individual metal particles were counted for each catalyst. The acidity of reduced catalysts were evaluated by temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of NH3 pre-adsorbed at 373K. NH3-TPD profiles were collected using an automatic Micromeritcs apparatus Model TPD/TPR 2900. 50mg of catalyst was loaded in a quartz tube and pretreated in He at 393K by 0.5h. After cooling, 50mLmin−1 of 5vol% NH3/He was passed through the sample for 0.5h at a constant temperature of 373K. Finally, the gaseous and weakly adsorbed ammonia were removed by a steady flow of He at 373K for 0.5h. The sample was then heated in 50mLmin−1 of He with a heating rate of 10Kmin−1 from 373 to 973K. The amount of NH3 desorbed was measured by a TCD which was previously calibrated. Structural characteristics of reduced catalysts were determined by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique which was recorded on a Bruker D4 Endeavor diffractometer, a Cu Kα radiation source was used with an accelerating voltage of 40kV and intensity of 20mA. Diffraction peaks were recorded in a 2θ range of 2–90° with step size of 0.02 and step scan of 0.02s. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to study chemical composition of the catalysts surfaces. Photoelectron spectra were recorded with a VG Escalab 200R electron spectrometer equipped with a MgKα X-ray source (hν =1253.6eV). The 50eV energy regions of the photoelectrons of interest were scanned a number of times to obtain an acceptable signal to noise ratio. Intensities were estimated by calculating the integral of each peak, determined by subtraction of the Shirley type background and fitting the experimental curve to a combination of Lorentzian and Gaussian lines (90G/10L). Accurate binding energies (0.2eV) were determined by referencing to the C 1s peak at 284.8eV. The reduction treatment was carried out in situ at 723K in a H2 flow for 120min. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation in the steam reforming of ethanol and characterization of used catalysts Activity tests were performed using 100mg of catalyst diluted with 200mg of SiC (both in the 0.18–0.36mm particle size range and selected after preliminary mass transport experiments to minimize diffusional resistances) to avoid adverse thermal effects. The catalyst bed was placed in a 1.7cm ID stainless steel tubular reactor with a coaxially centered thermocouple. Prior to reaction, the catalysts were heated in Ar flow (33mLmin−1) up to 773K (10Kmin−1), followed by reduction in situ at 773K for 1.5h with H2 flow (30mLmin−1), and subsequently by a purge with Ar flow (33mLmin−1) for 1h. The mixture water/ethanol (3/1 mole ratio) was fed from a liquid phase by a HPLC pump (Gilson 307) with a flow 0.09mLmin−1 and then it was entered using Ar carrier gas with a total flow of 137mLmin−1 (molar ratio Ar/(H2O+EtOH)=r.d=0.76) under a GHSV=26,000h−1 at atmospheric pressure. The catalytic activity was measured at 773K for 24h of time on stream in order to study the catalyst stability. The reaction products were followed using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Hiden Model HPR-20) connected on line to the reactor through a heated capillary tube. The transient-MS signals at m/z =2, 15, 18, 26, 28, 29, 30, 31, 44 and 58 were continuously recorded for H2, CH4, H2O, C2H4, CO, C2H4O, C2H6, C2H5OH, CO2 and C3H6O respectively. The intensity of each product was represented by the selected signal after subtracting the possible contributions of fragments from other compounds. Such contributions were calculated on the basis of the intensity ratios between the fragments characteristic of the individual molecules. Ethanol conversion, selectivity, and hydrogen yield were calculated from the following equations. Conversion : X ( % ) = Ethanol , in n − Ethanol , out n Ethanol , in n × 100 Selectivity : S ( % ) = n i Σ n n i × 100 H 2 yield = n H 2 , out n Ethanol , in where ni is the moles number of product i, n ethanol is the moles number of ethanol. The quantity of coke deposited on the spent catalysts was determined by temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) by thermogravimetry (TGA/SDTA851 Mettler Toledo), measuring the mass loss in the spent catalysts during oxidation. Each sample was previously heated up to 773K for 1h in N2 (10Kmin−1, 200mLmin−1) to remove volatile compounds adsorbed on catalyst surfaces. TPO were performed from 303K (5Kmin−1) until a final temperature of 1273K under flow of 20vol% O2 in N2. Quantification of coke deposited on catalysts was calculated according the equation: C = m coke m used catalyst × t where:m coke is the mass of coke deposited on the catalyst, calculated from TPO–TGA, m usedcatalyst is the mass of catalyst calculated from the mass remaining after the TG analysis, and t is the time under reaction. The nature and characteristics of carbon deposits were also studied by Raman spectroscopy. Raman spectra were recorded with a Renishaw in via Raman microscope spectrometer equipped with a laser beam emitting at 532nm, at 100mW output power. Spectra acquisition consisted of 5 accumulations of 5s each one, collected at room temperature. 2.4 In situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) Temperature-programmed desorption of ethanol (ethanol TPD), isothermal ethanol decomposition and isothermal ethanol steam reforming experiments were studied by DRIFTS. DRIFT spectra were performed with a JASCO FTIR 6300 spectrometer equipped with a liquid-nitrogen-cooled MCT detector and a KBr beam splitter. In situ experiments were performed using a DRIFT chamber (Spectra Tech) with ZnSe windows directly connected to a flow system equipped with mass flow controllers, saturators with ethanol and water, and a set of valves that allowed selection of feed gas composition (3/1 water/ethanol mole ratio). Following H2 pretreatment at 723K for 2h, the chamber was held for 0.5h under He to remove moisture generated from the reduction step. The DRIFT chamber outlet was connected on-line through a capillary tube maintained at 473K to an Omnistar/Pfeiffer Vacuum mass spectrometer (MS) which was used for monitoring of effluent gas composition. The transient-MS signals at m/z =2, 15, 18, 26, 28, 29, 30, 31 and 44 were continuously recorded for H2, CH4, H2O, C2H4, CO, C2H4O, C2H6, C2H5OH and CO2, respectively. For ethanol TPD experiments, ethanol was introduced into the DRIFT chamber by bubbling helium (30mLmin−1) through a saturator maintained at 303K by 0.5h. The first spectrum was recorded at room temperature after flushing under He flow for 0.5h. Then the temperature was increased stepwise up to 723K and spectra were recorded every 50K after equilibration for 2min on stream. For ethanol decomposition experiments at 723K, ethanol was introduced into the DRIFT chamber as mentioned above and spectra were recorded every 2min for 1h. In the case of ethanol steam reforming reaction at 723K, the H2O:C2H5OH mix (3:1) was fed with a saturator as was performed with ethanol. For isothermal experiments, only background at 723K was recorded. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Specific surface areas of the supports used in the study were determined applying the BET method to nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77K (Table 1 ). The specific area of the 2.5Ce-A support did not differ very much from that of the bare γ-Al2O3, indicating that the textural properties of the alumina support did not change significantly upon incorporating of CeO2 to the support. On the contrary, a different trend was observed on comparing the specific surface area of La-modified alumina. Textural data of the 15LA support showed that lanthanum incorporation to the alumina strongly diminished its specific surface area by the coverage of the pore walls of the γ-Al2O3 with the lanthanum species [32] and [33]. Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the reduced catalysts. All catalysts showed diffraction peaks at approximately 2θ =37.2°, 45.8° and 66.7°, which correspond to γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 86-1410). The XRD pattern of the Rh/2.5Ce-A catalyst exhibits diffraction lines only attributable to γ-Al2O3 and did not show any clear peaks associated to cerium species. The characteristic peaks of poorly crystalline γ-Al2O3 were also detected in the XRD pattern of both La-based catalysts (Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA). However, the addition of La2O3 caused a sharp decrease on the intensity of the Al2O3 peaks, which could be due to a structure disorder of the Al2O3 caused by lanthanum atoms highly dispersed on the Al2O3 structure [16,34]. No diffraction peaks corresponding to crystalline species of neither La2O3 (JCPDS 83-1355) or LaAlO3 (JCPDS 85-1071) were observed in the catalysts containing lanthanum. This indicates that lanthanum species are either incorporated into the pore structure of the alumina or highly dispersed on the surface as amorphous phases contributing to undetectable crystallites [35–37]. In all the catalysts, XRD diffraction peaks corresponding to Rh species were not detected because the concentration of Rh in the catalysts is below the XRD detection limit. The catalysts acidity has a significant effect on the catalytic activity for ESR and the resistance to coke deposition. Desorption temperatures and amount of ammonia desorbed are reported in Table 2 . All catalysts showed similar acid site distribution but differences in the acid site concentration. Catalyst supported on bare Al2O3 (Rh/A) shows an asymmetric desorption peak in the temperature range of 350–900K. Desorption peak displays a maximum at around 450K and a long tail. On the basis of data shown in Table 2, it is possible to suggest that the concentration of acid sites decreases with addition of CeO2 to γ-Al2O3. The decrease in total acidity of catalysts was less significant with the addition of La2O3 to γ-Al2O3 support [34], whereas both promoters sharply decreased its original strong acidity. The chemical species present on the catalysts surface and their proportions were evaluated by XPS. The binding energies of the most intense peaks of spectra are summarized in Table 3 . For La-containing catalysts, the La 3d5/2 peak was observed at 835.4–835.5eV and it is substantially higher than the values reported for La2O3 (833.2eV) and LaAlO3 (833.8eV) standards. However, it is similar to the binding energy observed by Alvero et al. [38], who attributed this higher binding energy to deficiently coordinated La3+ ions in La2O3/Al2O3 systems prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. The Ce 3d spectra of the cerium containing supports consist of several peaks resulting from either multiplet splitting or shake-up processes. The isolated peak in the Ce 3d spectra at ca. 917eV (u”' using the nomenclature of Burroughs) [39] has been used as identification of Ce4+ species and its relative peak area contribution to total Ce 3d area as quantitative measure of the amount of Ce4+. The fraction of the total Ce signal attributable to the u”' peak in the Ce-modified catalysts (ca. 12 %) indicated the presence of Ce3+ species in the reduced catalysts. The calculated XPS Ce/Al atomic ratio in the Rh/2.5Ce-A is higher than the expected value derived from nominal chemical composition, indicating the presence of an overlayer of cerium species in agreement with previous results reported by Damyanova et al. [40]. In the case of the Rh/2.5Ce–15La catalyst surface cerium species were detected at similar level to Rh/2.5Ce-A, indicating a preferential coverage of lanthanum on γ-Al2O3 after impregnation. The reduced catalysts showed Rh 3d5/2 peak at binding energy of 307.2–307.6eV. This peak can be ascribed to metallic rhodium, although the binding energy appears slightly above the Rh0 state. The observed shift in binding energy may be consequence of either the smaller size of the particles of rhodium or the strong interaction with support leading to an electronic polarization of the clusters of rhodium. 3.2 Catalysts stability in steam reforming of ethanol and characterization of used catalysts The catalysts stability during ethanol steam reforming was evaluated in terms of ethanol conversion and products distribution as a function of time on stream for 24h. The effect of the modification of the support with promoters on catalyst deactivation with time on stream and amount of coke deposited were evaluated. The experiments were performed at GHSV 26,000h−1 under very high inlet ethanol concentration (ca. 14vol%) and H2O to ethanol molar ratio of 3 and r.d of 0.76, using the right conditions to prevent the catalyst deactivation phenomena. Conversion and selectivity to gas products during 24h of time on stream is depicted in Fig. 2 . All catalysts attained complete conversion and displayed the same products but with different distribution. The main observed products were H2, CH4, CO, CO2 acetaldehyde, acetone and ethylene in all cases. At 0.5h to time on stream, the beginning of the reaction, Rh catalyst supported on bare Al2O3 (Fig. 2a) showed the highest selectivity to CO (ca. 19%) and to ethylene (ca. 14%) and the lowest to CH4 (<4%) compared with the other catalysts. The lower selectivity to CH4 relative to others catalysts could be due to a slow rate of desorption of the CH x species as CH4, which can lead to accumulation of these species [41]. Between doped catalysts two behaviours were observed. In the catalyst modified with 2.5%CeO2, selectivity follows the order: H2 >>CH4 ≈CO≈CO2, while for the La-modified catalysts, selectivity followed the order: H2 >>CH4 ≈CO2 >CO. In both cases selectivity to ethylene was below 1% at 0.5h on-stream. The very low selectivity to ethylene in these catalysts gives an indication that support modification, even with very low amounts of CeO2, disfavors the dehydration reaction observed in the bare alumina supported catalyst. However, after 2h on stream, selectivity to ethylene progressively increased in Ce-modified catalyst up to 36% at 5h, while selectivity to H2 is maintained sufficiently high (>50%). The ethylene product was mainly produced on supports acid sites by ethanol dehydration reaction. (2) CH3CH2 →2C2H4 +H2O and the ethylene production can be providing coke deposition: (3) C2H4 →2H2 +2C Until 5h-on-stream the increases of ethylene production was significant, but at 24h mainly kept constant (see Fig. 2b). Therefore, it can be speculated that the ethylene decomposition over the Rh/2.5Ce-A catalyst at short time did not contributed to a significant catalyst deactivation, but at long time-on-stream the coke deposition could be enough to block the metal and acid supports sites of the catalyst. Obviously, the presence of CeO2 promoter on the catalyst surface contributed to coke gasification, recovering the acid/metallic sites to transform ethanol into the products by dehydrogenation and/or decomposition on the catalyst surface (vida infra). It should be noted that Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA catalysts were stables during 5h on stream. The presence of 2.5% of CeO2 in the Rh /15LA catalyst slightly increased selectivity to H2 throughout the reaction. According to products distribution observed, it appears that ethanol and reaction intermediates such as acetaldehyde undergo decarbonylation (Eqs. (4) and (5)) and subsequent reactions that favor formation of CO2 (such as WGS reaction (Eq. (6)). On the other hand, the main reaction pathways on Rh/A catalysts were dehydration to produce ethylene, dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde species or direct ethanol decomposition. The WGS reaction is more favoured in all the doped catalysts compared with bare alumina. (4) CH3CH2OH→CH4 +CO+H2 (5) CH3CHO→CH4 +CO (6) CO+H2O→CO2 +H2 After 24h of reaction (Table 4 ), all catalysts showed decreased of selectivity to H2 to different extents and the conversion was maintained above 85%. In addition, a slight increase of selectivity to C2 and C3 species was observed in all cases. An increase in selectivity to acetaldehyde, ethylene and acetone in gas phase products after 24h of time on stream, in addition to the minimal selectivity to products from CC bond cleavage at the beginning of the reaction, confirms catalyst deactivation because of the diminished capacity of CC bond breakage. Nevertheless, doped catalyst with both promoters showed the lowest selectivity to these C2 and C3 products. The presence of acetone after 24h of time on stream points out that decarbonylation of acetaldehyde (Eq. (5)) competes with the formation of acetone (Eq. (7)). (7) 2CH3CHO+O(l) →CH3COCH3 +CO2 +H2(l)=lattice Although all catalysts showed deactivation at 24h of reaction, doped catalysts with La2O3 presented the lowest deactivation, being minor for catalyst with both promoters (Table 4). According to observed products, one of the main causes of deactivation in these systems was due to the deposition of carbonaceous species by: (i) ethanol dehydration to ethylene (Eq. (2)), followed by polymerization to coke (Eq. (3)) and (ii) aldol condensation of acetone followed by dehydration to mesityl oxide (MO) (Eq. (9)). The aldol condensation of acetone produces diacetone alcohol, which can subsequently suffer dehydration to mesityl oxide (MO) [42] whose oligomerization can lead to the formation of coke [43]. (9) 2CH3COCH3 →(CH3)2C(OH)CH2COCH3 →(CH3)2C=CHCOCH3 +H2O The early deactivation of Rh/A catalyst from the beginning of the reaction is due to polymerization reactions of ethylene that block the catalyst metal sites. As displayed in Fig. 2a, the bare alumina catalyst showed the highest selectivity to ethylene throughout the reaction. Polymerization of ethylene to coke takes place on both strong Bronsted and Lewis acid sites of the support that results in the formation of polynuclear hydrocarbons, which remain strongly adsorbed on acid sites and cause loss of activity or form coke multilayers that lead to catalyst poisoning [44]. As shown in NH3-TPD results (Table 2), the Rh/A catalyst presented the highest amount of strong acids sites (25%) which would promote ethanol dehydration and subsequent reactions from ethylene. The highest selectivity to ethylene throughout the reaction found for this catalyst is consistent with the carbon build-up observed by TPO–TG analysis (Table 4). Hence, an adequate control of the medium and strong acidity strength is necessary to inhibit coke formation, via ethylene, in alumina systems. During ESR, carbon could be mainly formed by two pathways, as was discussed previously. It should be noted that although the Rh/2.5Ce-A catalyst showed the lowest acidity, it exhibited a progressive enhancement of ethylene during the reaction; therefore, it is not sufficient to diminish the acidity to prevent formation of ethylene. The increase of selectivity to ethylene in this catalyst with time on stream is due to favorability in the pathway of ethanol dehydration in respect to ethanol dehydrogenation by changes in metallic phase. Such as was described by Mattos et al. [44], alumina promotes the dehydration of ethanol via an E2 mechanism, which requires strong Lewis acid sites and basic sites. According to NH3-TPD results, the Ce-modified catalyst has the lowest acidity but the highest amount of intermediate and strong acid sites (72%), which could be favoring ethanol dehydration. These results are in agreement with Morterraj et al. [45], who showed that the presence of low CeO2 loading adds a Lewis acidity of medium strength to the alumina mixed systems, as was observed in our systems. On the other hand, the increase in catalytic activity and resistance toward carbon formation of Rh/2.5Ce-A and Rh/2.5Ce-LA could be mainly due to the redox property of ceria. CeO2-based materials have high oxygen storage capacity and oxygen mobility. These characteristics are related to their rapid reduction/oxidation capability (Eq. (10)) due to the release and uptake of oxygen owing to the reversible reaction below [46]: (10) CeO2 ↔CeO2− x +O x where O x is the lattice oxygen at CeO2 surface. Carbon monoxide can adsorb and react with the lattice oxygen on the surface of ceria to form carbon dioxide (Eq. (11)), (11) CO+O x →CO2 +O x−1 where O x−1 is the reduced site of ceria. More CO2 are produced rather than CO, which can inhibit carbon deposition (Eqs. (10) and (11)). As a lattice oxygen provider, CeO2 may oxidize the solid carbon in the following reaction [47], (12) C(s) +O x →O x −1 +CO Similarly, in presence of lattice oxygen, Rh oxidation may also take place according to the following reaction, (13) zRh+O x →O x−y +Rh z O y It is unlikely that CeO2 oxidizes Rh to Rh z O y species, which has less catalyst activity than Rh. However, CeO2 possibly reacts with reduced sites of Ce, O x−1, as well as recover Rh metal to maintain the active phase activity for hydrogen production. On doped catalysts with La2O3 the formation of carbon is markedly suppressed as indicated by the lower carbon deposition rate (Table 4). Participation of lanthanum phase through formation of La2O2CO3 (Eq. (14)) can explain the differences in carbon formation on containing La-catalysts. It has been reported that the La2O2CO3 specie can reacts with carbon–metal species (CM n ) formed in its vicinity, to produce two molecules of CO (Eq. (15)) [48]. Thus, La2O3 acts as an intermediate, promoting the reaction between the carbon species and CO2. (14) La2O3 +CO2⇄La2O2CO3 (15) C–M n +La2O2CO3 →2CO+M n +La2O3 The doped catalyst with both promoters (Rh/2.5Ce–15LA) exhibited the lowest carbon deposition rate compared with the others catalysts and with some data reported in literature for similar systems [49,50]. The addition of low CeO2 loading (2.5%) and high La2O3 loading (15%) to Rh/A catalyst induced important changes in the acid–base properties of the support. As can be seen in Table 2, modification of alumina with these promoters generates a decrease in the concentration of total acid sites and the highest amount of weak acid sites (around 60%), resulting in lower production of ethylene and therefore less carbon deposits. Additionally, Al2O3 support modification with both promoters strongly influenced the stability of the catalyst during reforming reaction, in addition to contributing to reduce ethylene production by promoting the oxidation of carbon precursors deposited on rhodium surface during the reaction. On the other hand, the use of a low CeO2 loading contributed slightly to decrease of the carbon deposition rate due to its reduction/oxidation capability by the release and uptake of oxygen. The Rh/2.5Ce–15LA catalyst showed a lesser carbon deposition amount (see Table 4) because CeO2 and La2O3 promoters can help to remove the deposited carbon. On the other hand, the strong interaction between Rh and CeO2 over these catalysts prepared by the impregnation method can lead to an increase in the stability, because it could benefit the gasification of carbon and reactivation of the catalyst in a regeneration process. Fig. 3 shows the Raman spectra of the used catalysts. Used catalysts showed Raman bands at 1330 and 1600cm−1. The intensity of these bands practically disappears on Rh/2.5Ce–LA and Rh/LA. The band at ca. 1330cm−1 (D band) is associated with allotropic forms of carbon (carbon nanotubes, amorphous carbon, defective filamentous carbon) and the band at around 1600cm−1, the so-called G-mode, is attributed to presence of ordered carbon (graphite) [51]. The presence of both signals, G and D, shows the heterogeneity of the carbon species formed during the SRE. 3.3 Study of reaction pathways in ethanol steam reforming over Rh/Al2O3 catalyst modified by binary promoters 3.3.1 Temperature-programmed desorption of ethanol (Ethanol-TPD) The in situ DRIFT spectra obtained during ethanol TPD on reduced Rh/xCe–yLA catalysts are shown in Figs. 4 and 5 . At 303K, upon adsorption of ethanol, the IR bands at ca. 2970, 2930 and 2900cm−1, which are ascribed to ν as(CH3), ν as(CH2) and ν s(CH3), respectively, are observed in all catalysts (Fig. 4). These bands along with bands visible at 1450, 1390, 1163, 1100, 1080 and 1060cm−1 assigned to δ as(CH3), δ s(CH3), ν(CO or CC), ν as(CCO) monodentade, ν(CC) and ν as(CCO) bidentate, respectively (Fig. 5), demonstrate the existence of surface ethoxide species due to the ethanol adsorption [52–54]. In addition, a band at 1630–1650cm−1 that could be assigned to ν(CO) of the acetyl species [24,55,56], was also observed on the catalysts at 303K (Fig. 5). The acetyl species are produced by dehydrogenation of acetaldehyde species (Eq. (16)), which can confirm that dehydrogenation reaction of ethanol occurred on all the catalysts. Acetaldehyde was also observed on all the catalyst, confirmed by a band at 970cm−1, ascribed to the ρ(CH3) vibration in η 2(C,O)-acetaldehyde, [23]. At this temperature (330K), bands in the carbonyl region (1800–2030cm−1) typical of CO species linearly and bridged adsorbed on Rh particles was also observed, except for catalyst supported on bare alumina. Presence of adsorbed CO indicates an enhancement in activity for CC breakage at low temperature when the Rh particles were deposited on lanthanum and cerium-modified alumina. (16) CH3CHO(ads) →CH3CO(ads) +H(ads) The evolution of surface species on the catalysts with the increase in desorption temperature is different depending on the presence of promoters on the support. With the increase in desorption temperature (473K), the sample supported on bare alumina (Rh/A) showed a decrease in the intensity of bands corresponding to molecular ethanol and appearance of strong bands corresponding to carbonyls on Rh (linear and bridged). Similar behavior was observed during TPD of ethanol over Rh/2.5Ce-A catalyst (Fig. 5). On the contrary, the catalysts with lanthanum in the support (Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA) showed some differences in the evolution of surface species. Furthermore, with the increase in desorption temperature, absorption bands associated to carbonyl species on Rh, mainly in linear form, was detected on the Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA catalysts: the growth of a small band centered at 1570cm−1 was ascribed to the asymmetric vibration of the COO group in acetate species. The lowest formation of Rh2°(CO) observed is in agreement with the existence of the smallest Rh particles on La-doped catalysts (Table 1). With a progressive increase in temperature, an asymmetric broad band in the region of 1400–1600cm−1 grew on the Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA catalysts. This band could be associated to the increase of acetate species (1570 and 1450cm−1), but given its asymmetry and the shoulder at 1350cm−1, it is possible that formate groups also are present, as these species show bands in the same range (ca. 1570 and 1360cm−1) [57–59]. The lower intensity of the band at ca. 1450–cm−1, with respect to the band at ca. 1570cm−1 observed in these catalysts (Fig. 5), indicates that a minor amount of acetate is present with respect to the other species (formate), as the typical spectrum for acetate species show similar intensities for symmetric and asymmetric vibration bands while for formates species, the symmetric band is only about 1/3 of asymmetric band [60]. Formate species are produced from CO or HCO species in the presence of abundant surface oxygen or OH groups (Eqs. (15) and (16)) [59]. Coexistence of these species has already been reported by some authors [23,24]. For unmodified and Ce-modified catalysts, the increase in temperature mainly generated strong bands corresponding to CO species and small bands attributable to vibration of COO acetates. Above 623K, a sharp decrease of CO bands was observed for all catalysts and a stable signal acetate bands for Rh/A and Rh/2.5Ce-A. Erdohelyi et al. [52] suggested that highly stable acetate species hinder the migration of ethoxide species to the metal, and consequently its decomposition to H2 at the metal/support interface. Accumulation of acetate species on the catalyst surface can be responsible of deactivation shown in Rh/2.5Ce-A catalysts from 2h-on-stream, given that it shows good results at the beginning of the reaction. In case of La-modified catalysts, above 623K, an enhanced broad band between 1400 and 1600cm−1 was detected along with the appearance of several shoulders. These new signals can suggest formation of carbonate species (ν(CO)= ca. 1530–1560 and 1340–1380cm−1), considering the disappearance of the CH stretching vibrations in methyl groups (ca. 2970 and 2930cm−1) and symmetric and asymmetric CH vibrations in methylene groups (2900 and 2930cm−1), observed from 623K. The Rh/2.5Ce–15LA catalyst exhibited increased signal intensity attributed to the carbonate species and formates compared with Rh/15LA catalyst. This observation indicates that the addition of 2.5%CeO2 to the 15LA support favored the oxidation and decomposition of intermediates. (17) OH(ads) +CO(ads) ⇆HCOO(ads) (18) O(ads) +HCO(ads) ⇆HCOO(ads) Changes in gas phase composition during TPD of ethanol were monitored by mass spectrometry. As can be observed in Fig. 6 , gaseous products distribution obtained during TPD of ethanol depends on the support, though all catalyst showed the same products (H2, CO, CO2, CH3CHO, CH4). Doped catalysts exhibited higher amount of H2 and CO2 compared to catalyst supported on bare alumina. The C1 distribution observed points to the decomposition of ethanol goes mainly through oxidized intermediates such as acetates and/or formates in doped-catalysts, and was more favoured when lanthanum was present in the support. In the case of bare alumina (Rh/A in Fig. 6a) at the beginning of TPD test, the main gaseous products detected at low temperature were CH4 and CO with minimum detection of CO2. Hydrogen desorption signal was observed at higher temperature, revealing that hydrogen desorption was inhibited on this catalyst. The products distribution on this catalyst points to a direct ethanol decomposition and decomposition of intermediates, as operative pathways. Acetaldehyde intermediate is more stable on catalysts with CeO2, because it has a broader profile desorption. 3.3.2 Ethanol decomposition at 723K Fig. 7 shows DRIFT spectra of adsorbed species over catalysts during ethanol decomposition reaction at 723K. At the beginning of the ethanol decomposition reaction on catalyst supported on bare alumina (Rh/A Fig. 7a), a small vibration band at 1970cm−1, corresponding to CO lineally adsorbed on Rh particles, together with absorption bands ascribed to acetate species (1570 and 1460cm−1), was obseved. After 20min on-stream, the CO band increased slightly in intensity and the absorption bands corresponding to acetate species became more intense, with the appearance of new absorption bands at 1340 and 1650cm−1; this is indicative of the presence of formate and carbonate species accompanying acetate species. After 60min on-stream, the acetate absorption bands slightly increased inferring that these species accumulates during reaction and that it is likely responsible for catalyst deactivation observed at long reaction times. DRIFT spectra corresponding to ethanol decomposition over Rh/2.5Ce-A shows a behavior similar to that previously described for catalysts supported on bare alumina (Fig. 7b). In the case of catalysts with lanthanum in the support (Rh/15La and Rh/2.5Ce–15La, Fig. 7c and d respectively) the DRIFT profile spectra with time on-stream, shown from initial stage of the ethanol decomposition, reveals the coexistence of acetate and formates species, indicating a greater tendency to CC bond dissociation for these catalysts. Hence, support modification favors the intermediates decomposition. Fig. 8 shows the product distribution obtained from ethanol decomposition on Rh catalysts. Analysis of products showed differences between the catalysts depending on the presence of lanthanum in the support. At the beginning of the reaction, the catalysts supported on bare alumina and 2.5Ce-A (Rh/A and Rh/2.5Ce-A Fig. 8a and b respectively) mainly produced H2, CO, and CH4. The presence of H2, CO and CH4 on Rh/A and Rh/2.5Ce-A indicated the activity of the catalysts for the breaking of CC bonds of C2 intermediates. In the case of catalysts supported on lanthanum containing alumina (Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA, Fig. 8c and d respectively) the signal of methane was much higher than that observed on catalysts without lanthanum. The higher formation of H2 and CO observed for Rh/A and Rh/2.5Ce-A catalysts is due to the fact that decomposition reaction is favored (Eq. (4)). On the contrary, for the La-doped catalysts, the ethanol reaction mainly follows the ethanol dehydrogenation route and subsequent acetaldehyde decomposition to CH4 and CO. After 45min time-on-stream there was a change in the product distribution characterized by an increase in the signals of H2 and CO and a concomitant decrease in the CH4 and CO2 signals. The change in gas products indicated catalysts deactivation and hence the rate of ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde decreases, favoring the direct ethanol decomposition. In addition, the presence of ethanol and acetaldehyde in gas products confirms catalysts deactivation in all cases. 3.3.3 Ethanol steam reforming reaction at 723K The in situ DRIFT spectra obtained during ethanol steam reforming at 723K are shown in Fig. 9 . DRIFT spectra at the beginning of the reaction over catalysts without lanthanum (Rh/A and Rh/2.5Ce-A) showed absorption bands corresponding to CO adsorbed o metallic Rh sites (at ca. 2000 and 1800cm−1, associated with linear and bridged CO species) and weak bands at ca. 1570 and 1460cm−1 corresponding to acetate species. After 20min on stream, the absorption bands corresponding to CO decreased slightly while the acetate bands became slightly more intense and became the main adsorbed intermediates on the catalysts surfaces for long-time on stream. A shoulder at ca. 1360cm−1 suggests the formation of formate species; however, given the similar intensities for symmetric and asymmetric vibration bands for acetate as was mentioned above, acetate species were found in higher amount. The catalysts with lanthanum in the support (Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA, Fig. 9c and d) presented differences with respect to the species adsorbed on the catalyst supported on bare alumina. On catalysts modified with lanthanum the intensity and stability of CO species were higher than that observed on catalysts without lanthanum. Bands in the 1300 and 1700cm−1 region were associated to formate species coexisting with acetate and carbonate species, and become the main adsorbed species on these catalysts. In doped catalyst with both promoters, a higher intensity of these bands is observed from the beginning of the reaction, indicating a greater tendency in this catalyst to oxidation and decomposition of intermediates. This fact can be associated with increased mobility of oxygen by CeO2 loading in this catalyst. Fig. 10 shows the gas products distribution in the ethanol reforming reaction on Rh catalysts. Catalysts supported on bare Al2O3 or 2.5Ce-modified Al2O3 (Rh/A and Rh/2.5Ce-A, Fig. 10a and b, respectively) produces H2, CO, CH4 and CO2. The products distribution was found to be constant with time-on-stream. The reaction pathways for these catalysts are similar to those explained for ethanol decomposition, but in this case the WGS reaction is favored thanks to the presence of water in the reaction medium. The presence of lanthanum in the support modifies the products distribution with respect to that observed for catalysts without lanthanum. The steam reforming of ethanol over catalysts with lanthanum in the support (Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA, Fig. 10c and d, respectively) produced H2, CH4, CO2 and CO, with higher selectivity to CH4 and CO2 to that observed on catalysts without lanthanum, demonstrating that on these catalysts, ethanol is preferably dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde which undergoes further reactions. The higher selectivity to CO2 indicated that lanthanum promotes the WGS capacity of catalysts through the formation of the formate intermediates observed by DRIFTS (Fig. 9). According to the literature, these intermediates can decompose generating CO2 and H2 (Eq. (19)) [54,61,62]. (19) HCOO(ads) ⇄CO2 +1/2H2 Based on the results described it is possible to affirm that modification of the support affected the reaction pathways of ethanol reforming. The dehydration route was in effect inhibited on La-doped catalysts even at long reaction times. In addition to the formation of ethylene, other reaction routes occurred on unmodified and Ce-doped catalysts. According to product distribution and DRIFT results, ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde and direct ethanol decomposition were carried out on these catalysts. Acetaldehyde desorbs or undergoes oxidation to acetate species as was observed by DRIFT spectra. The polymerization of ethylene can lead to the accumulation of acetate species due to the decreased ability of CC bond breakage, both leading to catalyst deactivation as was seen in experiments of long reaction times. The direct decomposition of ethanol is favored over Rh catalysts, as has been widely described in the literature [63–67], and given the distribution of products, this could be the main reaction pathway for the unmodified catalyst. A different situation was observed in the Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA catalysts. Based on the DRIFT results and product selectivity, it is possible to affirm that the favored route for these catalysts is the dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde. Acetaldehyde can undergo an additionally hydrogen abstraction, which leads to the formation of acetyl species, which were observed by DRIFT up to 573K. This specie can also be oxidized to acetate species or suffer decomposition reaction. Acetate species can either accumulates on catalysts or be decomposes to CH4 and CO x . According to results on La-modified catalysts, acetate species leads to formation of formates and carbonates species, as a result of the CO2 observed. Likewise, CO produced at some stage of the decomposition can lead to the formation of formate species in the presence of abundant surface oxygen or OH groups, which occurred over the doped catalysts. This observation is related with a higher capacity for WGS reaction in these catalysts. Dehydrogenation of the ethoxy species to acetaldehyde is likely assisted by the metal particles, as well as the presence of labile O adatoms or hydroxyl groups located on the support [44]; therefore, catalysts with higher availability of oxygen will tend to follow the ethanol dehydration pathway, as with the catalysts doped with La2O3 and/or CeO2. With time on stream (24h), deactivation is observed on all catalysts, as C2 species were detected in gas products, though Ce and La-modified catalyst showed less deactivation, which was in line with lower carbon build up (Table 4). Addition of a low amount of CeO2 (2.5%) to Rh catalysts supported on 15%La2O3–Al2O3 impacted stability to the catalyst which was stable for 24h on stream and with a high molH2/molEthanol ratio of 3.3. CeO2 contributed to the removal of carbon deposits due to the high mobility of oxygen (Eq. (12)). Additionally, CeO2 favored oxidation of intermediates and its decomposition, avoiding acetate accumulation. 4 Conclusions Results obtained in this work showed that addition of 15wt%La2O3 and low Ce loading (2.5wt%) to γ-Al2O3 support play an essential role in the catalytic stability of Rh catalysts for the steam reforming of ethanol. As was seen, support modification with these promoters presented the lowest deactivation and coke formation and hence, it led to a more stable catalyst for longer reaction times. In the Rh/15LA and Rh/2.5Ce–15LA catalysts, the main reaction pathway for ethanol was found to be the dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde, stabilized on the surface by the presence of promoters, and its subsequent reactions of decomposition and oxidation. This reaction route displayed a high selectivity to H2 and a higher selectivity to CO2 than to CO, through the formation of formate intermediates. Analysis of the used catalysts showed that changes in reaction pathways associated to the presence of Ce and La in the γ-Al2O3 support also modifies the extent and type of carbon deposited on catalyst surfaces. Adding 2.5%CeO2 to Rh catalyst supported on 15%La2O3–Al2O3 decreased the carbon deposition rate by 27% relative to 15%La2O3–Al2O3 support and by 3% relative to bare alumina. The cooperative effect of both promoters could explain the differences in carbon formation on the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, Rh catalysts supported over bare γ-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 modified with different promoters (15wt%La2O3 and/or 2.5wt%CeO2) were reported. The catalysts were prepared by successive impregnation: first the rare earth oxide promoter and then Rh. Hydrogen production by ethanol steam reforming (ESR) over these catalysts was investigated. Among the catalysts, Rh/La2O3–CeO2–γ-Al2O3 catalyst shows the highest hydrogen yield as well as the best stability during the reaction. Reaction pathways of the ESR over these Rh catalysts are investigated from the analysis of the adsorbed species and gas phase products formed during temperature programmed desorption of ethanol and ethanol steam reforming reaction. The differences in the reaction pathways and products distribution are as a result of the modification of the stability of some reaction intermediates caused by the presence of a small quantity of CeO2 and La2O3 on the support surfaces: in effect, acetaldehyde was formed as an intermediate over the modified-γ-Al2O3 supported catalysts while in the case of the bare Al2O3 support the main route of the steam reforming reaction is the direct ethanol decomposition. Analysis of the used catalysts by XPS, TGA and RAMAN showed that changes in reaction pathways associated to the presence of promoters in the Al2O3 support also modifies the extension and type of carbon deposited on catalyst surfaces.
coredata.dc:title: Improved ethanol steam reforming on Rh/Al2O3 catalysts doped with CeO2 or/and La2O3: Influence in reaction pathways including coke formation
